docs.title: Signal Processing
docs.text:
Welcome to our website on Signal Processing.

Table of Contents

Please contact me on LinkedIn

Thanks! - Dan

docs.title: Site Checklist
docs.text:
1. Customize the fields in your mkdocs.yml file
  2. Configure Google Analytics to use the right site ID
  3. Make sure that your .gitignore file includes the site directory
  4. Test the build
  5. Make sure the Edit button appears
  6. Make sure that code color heightening renders correctly
  7. run git config advice.addIgnoredFile false

docs.title: Python
docs.text:
hello_string = "Hello World!"
print(hello_string)
x = 1
if x == 1:
    # indented four spaces
    print("x is 1.")

Thanks! - Dan

docs.title: ISO Definition
docs.text:
A term definition is considered to be consistent with ISO metadata registry guideline 11179 if it meets the following criteria:

  1. Precise
  2. Concise
  3. Distinct
  4. Non-circular
  5. Unencumbered with business rules

docs.title: Term
docs.text: This is the definition of the term.

docs.title: How We Built This Site
docs.text: This page describes how we built this website and some of the rationale behind why we made various design choices.

docs.title: Python
docs.text: MicroSims are about how we use generative AI to create animations and simulations. The language of AI is Python. So we wanted to create a site that could be easily understood by Python developers.

docs.title: Mkdocs vs. Docusaurus
docs.text: There are two main tools used by Python developers to write documentation: Mkdocs and Docusaurus. Mkdocs is easier to use and more popular than Docusaurus. Docusaurus is also optimized for single-page applications. Mkdocs also has an extensive library of themes and plugins. None of us are experts in JavaScript or React. Based on our ChatGPT Analysis of the Tradeoffs we chose mkdocs for this site management.

docs.title: GitHub and GitHub Pages
docs.text:
GitHub is a logical choice to store our site source code and documentation. GitHub also has a Custom GitHub Action that does auto-deployment if any files on the site change. We don't currently have this action enabled, but other teams can use this feature if they don't have the ability to do a local build with mkdocs.

GitHub also has Issues, Projects and releases that we can use to manage our bugs and tasks.

The best practice for low-cost websites that have public-only content is GitHub Pages. Mkdocs has a command (mkdocs gh-deploy) that does deployment directly to GitHub Pages. This was an easy choice to make.

docs.title: GitHub Clone
docs.text:
If you would like to clone this repository, here are the commands:

mkdir projects
cd projects
git clone https://github.com/dmccreary/microsims

docs.title: After Changes
docs.text:
After you make local changes you must do the following:

# add the new files to a a local commit transaction
git add FILES
# Execute the a local commit with a message about what and why you are doing the commit
git commit -m "comment"
# Update the central GitHub repository
git push

docs.title: Material Theme
docs.text:
We had several options when picking a mkdocs theme:

  1. Mkdocs default
  2. Readthedocs
  3. Third-Party Themes See Ranking

The Material Theme had 16K stars. No other theme had over a few hundred. This was also an easy design decision.

One key criterial was the social Open Graph tags so that when our users post a link to a simulation, the image of the simulation is included in the link. Since Material supported this, we used the Material theme. You can see our ChatGPT Design Decision Analysis if you want to check our decision process.

docs.title: Enable Edit Icon
docs.text:
To enable the Edit icon on all pages, you must add the edit_uri and the content.action.edit under the theme features area.

edit_uri: edit/master/docs/

    theme:
        features:
            - content.action.edit

docs.title: Conda vs VENV
docs.text:
There are two choices for virtual environments. We can use the native Python venv or use Conda. venv is simle but is only designed for pure Python projects. We imagine that this site could use JavaScript and other langauges in the future, so we picked Conda. There is nothing on this microsite that prevents you from using one or the other. See the ChatGPT Analysis Here.

Here is the conda script that we ran to create a new mkdocs environment that also supports the material social imaging libraries.

conda deactivate
conda create -n mkdocs python=3
conda activate mkdocs
pip install mkdocs "mkdocs-material[imaging]"

docs.title: Mkdocs Commands
docs.text: There are three simple mkdoc commands we use.

docs.title: Local Build
docs.text:
mkdocs build

This builds your website in a folder called site. Use this to test that the mkdocs.yml site is working and does not have any errors.

docs.title: Run a Local Server
docs.text:
mkdocs serve

This runs a server on http://localhost:8000. Use this to test the display formatting locally before you push your code up to the GitHub repo.

mkdoc gh-deploy

This pushes everything up to the GitHub Pages site. Note that it does not commit your code to GitHub.

docs.title: Mkdocs Material Social Tags
docs.text:
We are using the Material Social tags. This is a work in progress!

Here is what we have learned.

  1. There are extensive image processing libraries that can't be installed with just pip. You will need to run a tool like brew on the Mac to get the libraries installed.
  2. Even after brew installs the libraries, you have to get your environment to find the libraries. The only way I could get that to work was to set up a local UNIX environment variable.

Here is the brew command that I ran:

brew install cairo freetype libffi libjpeg libpng zlib

I then had to add the following to my ~/.zshrc file:

export DYLD_FALLBACK_LIBRARY_PATH=/opt/homebrew/lib

Note that I am running on a Mac with Apple silicon. This means that the image libraries that brew downloads must be specific to the Mac Arm instruction set.

  • Cover images for blog post #4364
  • Discussion on overriding the Social Card Image

docs.title: Site References
docs.text:
1. mkdocs - https://www.mkdocs.org/ - this is our tool for building the website. It converts Markdown into HTML in the site directory.
  2. mkdocs material theme - https://squidfunk.github.io/mkdocs-material/ - this is the theme for our site. The theme adds the user interface elements that give our site the look and feel. It also has the features such as social cards.
  3. GitHub Pages - https://pages.github.com/ - this is the free tool for hosting public websites created by mkdocs
  4. Markdown - https://www.mkdocs.org/user-guide/writing-your-docs/#writing-with-markdown - this is the format we use for text. It allows us to have headers, lists, tables, links and images without learning HTML.
  5. Deploy Mkdocs GitHub Action - https://github.com/marketplace/actions/deploy-mkdocs - this is the tool we use to automatically build our site after edits are checked in with Git.
  6. Git Book - https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2 - a useful book on Git. Just read the first two chapters to learn how to check in new code.
  7. Conda - https://conda.io/ - this is a command line tool that keeps our Python libraries organized for each project.
  8. VS Code - https://code.visualstudio.com/ - this is the integrated development environment we use to mange the files on our website.
  9. Markdown Paste - https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=telesoho.vscode-markdown-paste-image - this is the VS code extension we use to make sure we keep the markdown format generated by ChatGPT.

docs.title: Chapter 1: Introduction to Signal Processing
docs.text: This chapter provides an overview of signal processing, its importance in modern technology, and its various applications across different fields.

docs.title: What is Signal Processing?
docs.text:
• Definition of Signals and Systems: Understanding the basic concepts of signals (both continuous and discrete) and systems.
  • Historical Background: Evolution of signal processing from analog to digital.

docs.title: Importance of Signal Processing
docs.text:
• Applications in Daily Life: Communication systems, multimedia, healthcare, etc.
  • Role in Modern Technology: Internet of Things (IoT), autonomous vehicles, and more.

docs.title: Overview of the Course
docs.text:
• Course Objectives: What students will learn and achieve.
  • Structure and Prerequisites: How the course is organized and foundational knowledge required.

docs.title: Chapter 2: Mathematical Foundations
docs.text: Covers the essential mathematical tools required for signal processing, including linear algebra, complex numbers, and probability theory.

docs.title: Linear Algebra Review
docs.text:
• Vectors and Matrices: Operations, properties, and applications.
  • Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors: Their role in system analysis.

docs.title: Complex Numbers and Functions
docs.text:
• Complex Arithmetic: Addition, multiplication, and representation.
  • Phasors and Exponentials: Application in signal representation.

docs.title: Probability and Statistics
docs.text:
• Random Variables: Definitions and properties.
  • Statistical Measures: Mean, variance, and correlations.

docs.title: Chapter 3: Continuous-Time Signals and Systems
docs.text:
--

Introduces continuous-time signals and systems, including their classifications and properties.

docs.title: Signal Classification
docs.text:
• Deterministic vs. Random Signals
  • Periodic vs. Aperiodic Signals

docs.title: System Properties
docs.text:
• Linearity and Time-Invariance
  • Causality and Stability

docs.title: Convolution in Continuous Time
docs.text:
• Impulse Response
  • System Output Calculation

docs.title: Chapter 4: Discrete-Time Signals and Systems
docs.text: Focuses on discrete-time signals, systems, and the mathematical tools used to analyze them.

docs.title: Sampling and Quantization
docs.text:
• Nyquist-Shannon Sampling Theorem
  • Aliasing Effects

docs.title: Discrete-Time Convolution
docs.text:
• Impulse Response in Discrete Systems
  • Difference Equations

docs.title: Z-Transform
docs.text:
• Definition and Properties
  • Region of Convergence

docs.title: Chapter 5: Fourier Analysis
docs.text: Explores Fourier series and transforms for both continuous and discrete signals.

docs.title: Fourier Series
docs.text:
• Representation of Periodic Signals
  • Convergence Conditions

docs.title: Continuous-Time Fourier Transform (CTFT)
docs.text:
• Spectrum Analysis
  • Properties of CTFT

docs.title: Discrete-Time Fourier Transform (DTFT)
docs.text:
• Frequency Representation of Discrete Signals
  • Properties and Applications

docs.title: Chapter 6: Discrete Fourier Transform (DFT) and Fast Fourier Transform (FFT)
docs.text: Delves into the DFT and FFT algorithms used for efficient computation of Fourier transforms.

docs.title: Discrete Fourier Transform
docs.text:
• Definition and Computation
  • Circular Convolution

docs.title: Fast Fourier Transform Algorithms
docs.text:
• Radix-2 FFT
  • Computational Complexity

docs.title: Applications of DFT and FFT
docs.text:
• Signal Filtering
  • Spectral Analysis

docs.title: Chapter 7: The Z-Transform and Its Applications
docs.text: Introduces the Z-transform as a tool for analyzing discrete-time systems.

docs.title: Z-Transform Basics
docs.text:
• Definition and Inverse Z-Transform
  • Properties and Theorems

docs.title: Pole-Zero Analysis
docs.text:
• Stability and Causality
  • Frequency Response from Poles and Zeros

docs.title: Application in System Analysis
docs.text:
• Transfer Function Representation
  • System Design Techniques

docs.title: Chapter 8: Filter Design and Implementation
docs.text: Covers the principles and methods for designing digital filters.

docs.title: Types of Filters
docs.text:
• Low-Pass, High-Pass, Band-Pass, Band-Stop
  • FIR vs. IIR Filters

docs.title: FIR Filter Design
docs.text:
• Window Method
  • Frequency Sampling Method

docs.title: IIR Filter Design
docs.text:
• Analog Filter Approximation
  • Bilinear Transformation

docs.title: Implementation Considerations
docs.text:
• Finite Word Length Effects
  • Real-Time Processing Constraints

docs.title: Chapter 9: Adaptive Signal Processing
docs.text: Discusses adaptive filtering techniques and their applications in dynamic environments.

docs.title: Introduction to Adaptive Filters
docs.text:
• Need for Adaptation
  • Adaptive Filter Structures

docs.title: Adaptive Algorithms
docs.text:
• Least Mean Squares (LMS)
  • Recursive Least Squares (RLS)

docs.title: Applications
docs.text:
• Noise Cancellation
  • System Identification

docs.title: Chapter 10: Stochastic Processes and Random Signals
docs.text: Introduces the statistical treatment of signals and systems.

docs.title: Random Processes
docs.text:
• Classification of Random Processes
  • Stationarity and Ergodicity

docs.title: Statistical Averages
docs.text:
• Mean, Autocorrelation, and Autocovariance
  • Cross-Correlation Functions

docs.title: Response of Linear Systems to Random Inputs
docs.text:
• Output Mean and Variance
  • Spectral Characteristics

docs.title: Chapter 11: Spectral Estimation
docs.text: Explores techniques for estimating the spectral content of signals.

docs.title: Non-Parametric Methods
docs.text:
• Periodogram
  • Modified Periodogram

docs.title: Parametric Methods
docs.text:
• Autoregressive (AR) Models
  • Model Order Selection

docs.title: Applications
docs.text:
• Power Spectrum Analysis
  • Signal Detection

docs.title: Chapter 12: Time-Frequency Analysis and Wavelets
docs.text: Introduces methods for analyzing signals in both time and frequency domains simultaneously.

docs.title: Limitations of Fourier Transform
docs.text:
• Time-Frequency Trade-Off
  • Non-Stationary Signals

docs.title: Short-Time Fourier Transform (STFT)
docs.text:
• Windowing Concepts
  • Spectrogram Interpretation

docs.title: Wavelet Transform
docs.text:
• Continuous and Discrete Wavelets
  • Multi-Resolution Analysis

docs.title: Applications
docs.text:
• Signal Compression
  • Feature Extraction

docs.title: Chapter 13: Multirate Signal Processing
docs.text: Discusses processing techniques involving multiple sampling rates.

docs.title: Fundamentals of Multirate Systems
docs.text:
• Upsampling and Downsampling
  • Decimators and Interpolators

docs.title: Polyphase Decomposition
docs.text:
• Efficient Filter Implementations
  • Applications in DSP

docs.title: Filter Banks
docs.text:
• Analysis and Synthesis Banks
  • Applications in Subband Coding

docs.title: Chapter 14: Signal Compression and Coding
docs.text: Covers methods for reducing the data rate of signals while preserving essential information.

docs.title: Lossless Compression Techniques
docs.text:
• Entropy Coding
  • Huffman and Arithmetic Coding

docs.title: Lossy Compression Techniques
docs.text:
• Transform Coding
  • Quantization Strategies

docs.title: Standards and Applications
docs.text:
• JPEG, MPEG
  • Audio and Video Streaming

docs.title: Chapter 15: Machine Learning in Signal Processing
docs.text: Integrates machine learning algorithms into signal processing tasks.

docs.title: Overview of Machine Learning
docs.text:
• Basic Concepts
  • Supervised vs. Unsupervised Learning

docs.title: Feature Engineering
docs.text:
• Feature Extraction Methods
  • Dimensionality Reduction

docs.title: Classification and Regression
docs.text:
• Support Vector Machines
  • Neural Networks

docs.title: Applications
docs.text:
• Pattern Recognition
  • Anomaly Detection

docs.title: Chapter 16: Deep Learning and Neural Networks
docs.text:
-

Focuses on advanced neural network architectures and their applications in signal processing.

docs.title: Deep Learning Basics
docs.text:
• Introduction to Deep Neural Networks
  • Training Deep Networks

docs.title: Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs)
docs.text:
• Architecture Details
  • Application in Image Processing

docs.title: Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs)
docs.text:
• Sequence Modeling
  • Applications in Speech Recognition

docs.title: Generative Models
docs.text:
• Autoencoders
  • Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs)

docs.title: Chapter 17: Applications in Communications and Radar
docs.text: Explores signal processing techniques specific to communication systems and radar technology.

docs.title: Digital Communication Systems
docs.text:
• Modulation and Demodulation Techniques
  • Channel Equalization

docs.title: Signal Detection in Noise
docs.text:
• Detection Theory
  • Matched Filters

docs.title: Radar Signal Processing
docs.text:
• Pulse Compression
  • Doppler Processing

docs.title: Chapter 18: Signal Processing for Multimedia
docs.text: Discusses the processing of audio, image, and video signals for multimedia applications.

docs.title: Audio Signal Processing
docs.text:
• Speech Synthesis and Recognition
  • Audio Effects and Enhancements

docs.title: Image Processing
docs.text:
• Filtering and Edge Detection
  • Segmentation and Morphology

docs.title: Video Processing
docs.text:
• Motion Estimation
  • Video Stabilization

docs.title: Virtual and Augmented Reality
docs.text:
• Signal Processing Challenges
  • Immersive Technologies

docs.title: Chapter 19: Emerging Topics in Signal Processing
docs.text: Introduces cutting-edge areas in signal processing research and development.

docs.title: Compressed Sensing
docs.text:
• Theory and Principles
  • Recovery Algorithms

docs.title: Cognitive Signal Processing
docs.text:
• Adaptive Learning Systems
  • Applications in Smart Devices

docs.title: Quantum Signal Processing
docs.text:
• Quantum Computing Basics
  • Potential Signal Processing Applications

docs.title: Chapter 20: Integration of AI and Education in Signal Processing
docs.text: Explores the role of AI in revolutionizing signal processing education, including curriculum development and innovative teaching methods.

docs.title: AI in Curriculum Development
docs.text:
• Incorporating AI Modules
  • Interdisciplinary Approaches

docs.title: Gamification in Education
docs.text:
• Educational Games for Signal Processing
  • Engagement and Motivation Strategies

docs.title: Large Language Models (LLMs)
docs.text:
• Using LLMs as Educational Tools
  • Automated Tutoring Systems

docs.title: Future Directions
docs.text:
• Lifelong Learning Paradigms
  • Ethical Considerations in AI Education

This structured outline provides a comprehensive college-level course in signal processing, integrating traditional topics with modern advancements such as AI and machine learning, as reflected in the IEEE Signal Processing Magazine. Each chapter builds upon the previous ones, ensuring a cohesive learning journey.
